Why bid me to tune the light reed,</br>The pipe of the mirth-loving Muse;</br>Why bid me to quit the green mead,</br>And mansions less painful to chuse?</br>Ye know not the state of my breast!</br>Never swain was so wretched before;</br>I can never — no, never, find rest;</br>Pastorella, alas!  is no more.

Pastorella was queen of the plains,</br>Indeed was she modest and fair!</br>Our music enchanted the swains,</br>As I pip'd to her tuneful guittar;</br>The shepherds came round in a row,</br>And presented my fair-one with flowers:</br>Their flocks were much whiter than snow,</br>But they were no so happy as ours.

She was fair as the posey-wreath'd maid,</br>On the plains of Arcadia who dwells;</br>Her blushes more sweetness display'd,</br>Than the sun when the dew-drop dispels:</br>Near this fountain she wove me a wreath,</br>And in ev'ry rose dwelt a dart;</br>Young Cupid sat lurking beneath,</br>And planted them all in my heart.

Her crook I with roses bedeck'd,</br>A garland of marj'ram I wove:</br>How little I then did expect,</br>So soon to be robb'd of my love!</br>I sung her a rustical glee,</br>She seem'd to be pleas'd with the song;</br>Ah, fool — I was not to forsee,</br>Such happiness could not last long!

Young Felix retires from the train,</br>And says that his Chloe's unkind;</br>The youth is a true-hearted swain,</br>But jealousy tortures his mind.</br>I tell him my griefs!  all the while,</br>By fate how severerly I'm cross'd!</br>But he ne'er saw my shepherdess smile,</br>So he knows not how much I have lost.

"Beware!" said she, "Damon, the youth</br>Who loves on thy worth to discourse;</br>Who sets forth thy honour and truth,</br>And praises thy skill in the course!</br>Tho' he praise Damon's well-brandish'd lance,</br>When Damon to woodlands depart;</br>Tho' he praise Damon's step in the dance,</br>Believe not it comes from his heart!

"Beware too," said she, "the fond maid,</br>Who looks on my Damon, and sighs;</br>Whose cheeks are in blushes array'd,</br>While love bursts unbid from her eyes!</br>She envies my Damon and me:</br>She is fairer, I will not deny;</br>But it's Damon's alone best to see,</br>How much she is fairer than I.

"She will twine thee a garland of flowers;</br>Her groves are by Nature more grac'd:</br>Her roses are brighter than ours,</br>Than ours which deck the wide waster.</br>Her melody, too, is divine;</br>In the dance she no doubt can excel;</br>Her powers are greater than mine,</br>But, Damon — she loves not so well!"

This my shepherdess said, with a smile;</br>That smile which must charm me no more!</br>I gaz'd on her beauties the while,</br>Which, now, but in thought I adore:</br>Reflection brings strongly to mind</br>Every word that escap'd her dear tongue;</br>A charm in each sonnet I find,</br>If that sonnet my charmer e'er sung.

She was tending her innocent sheep,</br>By the current which runs thro' yon wood;</br>The margin was grassy and steep,</br>A lambkin roll'd into the flood.</br>She stoop'd; but, alas!  stoop'd too far;</br>Ah, then, how ill-fated was I!</br>She call'd on her Damon so dear;</br>She call'd, but no Damon was nigh.

Ah, me!  in that moment of pain,</br>No friend to retrieve her lost step;</br>No shepherdess, kindly, or swain,</br>To snatch the dear maid from the deep!</br>I wander'd about all the night,</br>No tidings of comfort I heard;</br>Aurora diffus'd her blest light;</br>The star of the morning appear'd.

O why, in that heart-thrilling hour,</br>Was I doom'd such a sight to behold!</br>Alone, and neglected, her bower,</br>Her lambkins stray'd far from the fold:</br>I cast my eyes over the plain,</br>And saw her stretch'd out on a bier,</br>Borne by shepherds; and every fond swain</br>Besprinkled each step with a tear.

The myrtle's beginning to fade—</br>'Tis time! — ne'er to blossom anew;</br>Since Damon has lost the dear maid,</br>That gave it it's fragrance and hue:</br>She will ne'er to his eye display charms,</br>Ne'er flourish beneath the bless'd sun;</br>Pastorella is torn from his arms,</br>And Damon is lost and undone!

Ye swains, strew her grave with sweet thyme,</br>Plant the lily and harebell around;</br>She fell, in her beauty and prime,</br>As a blossom that drops to the ground:</br>Bring each herb that exhales a perfume,</br>Each flower that in season appears;</br>They will ever continue to bloom,</br>While I water them thus with my tears.</br>
